nodes.text: Machine learning algorithms can be used to predict stock market values and thereby help investors make better buy and sell decisions
Stock market prediction is important and challenging because market values change dynamically and affect investor profit and national economic growth

This paper is a systematic literature review (SLR) that searched major digital libraries (Elsevier, ACM, IEEE, Google Scholar), screened 550 papers down to 45 using title, abstract and full text screening
Inclusion criteria: papers in English, fully available, and relevant to stock market prediction; quality assessed by analyzing each paper's author contribution
The review defines three research questions: RQ1 why stock prediction is necessary for investors; RQ2 what attributes/factors can be used; RQ3 what machine learning algorithms are used
Accurate machine learning based predictions can reduce investor risk, inform timing of buy/sell decisions, and increase profits

Common predictive attributes identified in the literature include market history, news and event information, public mood (social media), commodity prices, interest rates, foreign exchange, oil, gold and other macroeconomic indicators
Empirical studies report that combining event knowledge or news features with machine learning models (for example neural networks) increased prediction accuracy by about five percent in experiments
Machine learning algorithms used across studies include linear regression, neural networks, genetic algorithms, support vector machines, k-nearest neighbor, and random forest
Multiple studies reported SVM performs better than several other classification methods for predicting stock movement direction
Reported accuracy for random forest varies across studies (example reported values: 83% in one study, 64% in another), indicating variable performance by dataset and setup
Some multi-classifier experiments achieved around 65% accuracy and note that accuracy can improve with more effective attributes and larger training datasets
Practical implication: investors, sellers and brokers can gain benefits from accurate price direction prediction by optimizing buy and sell timing
Typical methodology in reviewed studies: train algorithms on historical price datasets and augment inputs with news or social media features to predict next-day or short-term price direction
Limitation: stock market prediction remains difficult due to many affecting events and market complexity, causing variability in algorithm performance and limiting generalizability

Conclusion from the literature: ML techniques are widely applied with varied success; selecting appropriate algorithms and input attributes, and incorporating event/news information can improve accuracy but challenges and inconsistent results persist
